urls.title: Widget behavior - Streamlit Docs
urls.description: We would like to use cookies to help us understand how users interact with this website. This is used, for example, to find out which parts of this site should be further improved. Widgets (like st.button, st.selectbox, and st.text_input) are at the heart of Streamlit apps. They are the interactive elements of Streamlit that pass information from your users into your Python code. Widgets are magical and often work how you want, but they can have surprising behavior in some situations. Understanding the

text:
Who loves widgets? 🙋

Check out the new guide in the docs to get a better understanding of their behavior beyond the basics: https://t.co/L9hExS5U23 

The guide covers simpler to more advanced concepts and dives into anatomy, statefulness, life cycles, and more! ✨ https://t.co/7pKggkO4iv

RT @ThiagoTDotCom: Just saw a super cool little demo from @AndrewYNg using @streamlit with @whitphx's WebRTC component! 

https://t.co/cLjD…

@shauryr @weaviate_io @clarifai @AssemblyAI @LangChainAI @llama_index Hey @shauryr,  

Thanks for reaching out! The app is set to an OR operation by default, but you can adjust the Boolean search to AND in the sidebar. 🎈

urls.title: (PUBLIC) Streamlit App Testing Framework - PREVIEW
urls.description: 🎈Streamlit App Testing Framework (PREVIEW) Streamlit app testing framework enables developers to build and run headless tests that execute their app code directly, simulate user input, and inspect rendered outputs for correctness. The provided class, AppTest, simulates a running app and provide...

text: 📄 You can read more about this upcoming feature here: https://t.co/teXWAdemur

⚙️ We're working on a new feature and would love to get your feedback!

App testing makes it dramatically easier to build automated tests for your app. Try the preview here: https://t.co/bRJF2ZtD51

Let us know what you think in the comments. ❤️

text:
🎉 It’s now possible to initialize selectboxes and a range of other widgets with an empty state! 

Simply set `index=None` or `value=None` to display the widget with no default value, and clearly see when a user has provided input.

Try it in release 1.27: https://t.co/EeNJRzQOmD https://t.co/HTdtRV7i31

urls.title: st.link_button - Streamlit Docs
urls.description: We would like to use cookies to help us understand how users interact with this website. This is used, for example, to find out which parts of this site should be further improved. Display a link button element. When clicked, a new tab will be opened to the specified URL. This will create a new session for the user if directed within the app. A short label explaining to the user what this button is for. The label can optionally contain Markdown and supports the following elements: Bold, Italics, Strikethrou

text:
🔗 Want to add more fun to external links in your apps?

Introducing st​.link_button! Display a button that when clicked, opens a new tab to a specified URL.
    
Learn more in the docs: https://t.co/pxCxt6qYTY https://t.co/lMCsrIFlme

urls.title: Supercharge Snowflake Development with Snowpark, DevOps, and AI
urls.description: Virtual Event - Join us virtually on September 27th for the next Generative AI User Group Meeting! This meeting will be a discussion between Kaarthik Andavar, creator SnowDev, and Tony Kipkemboi, Developer Relations at Snowflake. SnowDev is a command-line utility designed for deploying various components related to Snowflake such as UDFs, stored procedures, and Streamlit applications using Snowpark.

urls.title: Chart elements - Streamlit Docs
urls.description: Streamlit supports several different charting libraries, and our goal is to continually add support for more. Right now, the most basic library in our arsenal is Matplotlib. Then there are also interactive charting libraries like Vega Lite (2D charts) and deck.gl (maps and 3D charts). And finally we also provide a few chart types that are "native "to Streamlit, like st.line_chart and st.area_chart. st.line_chart(my_data_frame) Display an area chart. st.area_chart(my_data_frame) Display a bar chart.

text:
📈 Built-in chart elements now have a color parameter to set the color of your data points or series.

📑 Docs: https://t.co/DKZKD2WLQs

3/5 https://t.co/2NWL5qR9zx

urls.title: st.markdown - Streamlit Docs
urls.description: st.markdown displays string formatted as Markdown.

text:
🌈 st.markdown now supports grey and rainbow colored text!

Just use the syntax :color[text to be colored] and replace `color` with rainbow, grey...or any of the the other supported colors. 🤩

📑 Docs: https://t.co/JvSuSHcpul

2/5 https://t.co/HVJPHkP5MC

urls.title: Stlite Sandbox
urls.description: A Python library with useful Streamlit extras

text:
@arnaudmiribel 📦 Stlite sandbox

Execute untrusted code inside a sandboxed environment by using @whitphx's stlite instead of the app server. This is useful for apps that generate and execute code at runtime based on some user instructions.

https://t.co/h8gAnx6g5p 

🧵 6/9 https://t.co/d2FC5UdoCV

entity.description: The animated series is not for children. In fact, its goal seems to be to offend as many as possible as it presents the adventures of Stan, Kyle, Kenny and Cartman. The show has taken on Saddam Hussein, Osama bin Laden, politicians of every stripe and self-important celebrities. Oh, and Kenny is killed in many episodes.

entity.name: Rick and Morty
entity.description: After having been missing for nearly 20 years, Rick Sanchez suddenly arrives at daughter Beth's doorstep to move in with her and her family. Although Beth welcomes Rick into her home, her husband, Jerry, isn't as happy about the family reunion. Jerry is concerned about Rick, a sociopathic scientist, using the garage as his personal laboratory. In the lab, Rick works on a number of sci-fi gadgets, some of which could be considered dangerous. But that's not all Rick does that concerns Jerry. He also goes on adventures across the universe that often involve his grandchildren, Morty and Summer.

urls.title: Connections Hackathon
urls.description: Announcing the Streamlit Connections Hackathon 🎉 Configuring data connections can be one of the most frustrating and time-consuming parts of building robust Streamlit apps. You have to locate and install external packages, determine the best way to securely manage your credentials, and figure out how to retrieve the data you need in the desired format. Fortunately, with our recent release of st.experimental_connection, you can easily connect your Streamlit apps to data and APIs in just ...

text:
📣 Today's the last day of the Connections Hackathon!

We've seen hundreds of great projects so far. 🤩 You still have until 12am PDT to submit yours: https://t.co/fIzTYPsjsY 

🏆 The top 5 connections will be featured in the Streamlit docs. Winners announced Friday, August 11th.

urls.title: Build conversational apps - Streamlit Docs
urls.description: The advent of large language models like GPT has revolutionized the ease of developing chat-based applications. Streamlit offers several Chat elements, enabling you to build Graphical User Interfaces (GUIs) for conversational agents or chatbots. Leveraging session state along with these elements allows you to construct anything from a basic chatbot to a more advanced, ChatGPT-like experience using purely Python code. In this tutorial, we' ll start by walking through Streamlit's chat elements, st.chat_messa

urls.description: Most Streamlit apps need some kind of data or API access to be useful - either retrieving data to view or saving the results of some user action. This data or API is often part of some remote service, database, or other data source. Anything you can do with Python, including data connections, will generally work in Streamlit. Fortunately, with our recent release of st.experimental_connection, you can easily connect your Streamlit apps to data and APIs in just ...

urls.title: Button behavior and examples - Streamlit Docs
urls.description: Buttons created with st.button do not retain state. They return True on the script rerun resulting from their click and immediately return to False on the next script rerun. If a displayed element is nested inside if st.button(' Click me'):, the element will be visible when the button is clicked and disappear as soon as the user takes their next action. This is because the script reruns and the button return value becomes False. In this guide, we will illustrate the use of buttons and explain common

text:
🔘 Let's talk buttons!

This new guide in the docs goes over the use of buttons in Streamlit and explains common misconceptions. 🎈

📖 See examples of st.button using Session State, anti-patterns to look out for, and more: https://t.co/efo5LdJ0ak https://t.co/NFxsY6C44V

urls.title: Chat elements - Streamlit Docs
urls.description: Streamlit provides a few commands to help you build conversational apps. These chat elements are designed to be used in conjunction with each other, but you can also use them separately. st.chat_message lets you insert a chat message container into the app so you can display messages from the user or the app. Chat containers can contain other Streamlit elements, including charts, tables, text, and more. st.chat_input lets you display a chat input widget so the user can type in a message. Insert a chat me

urls.title: Build conversational apps - Streamlit Docs
urls.description: The advent of large language models like GPT has revolutionized the ease of developing chat-based applications. Streamlit offers several Chat elements, enabling you to build Graphical User Interfaces (GUIs) for conversational agents or chatbots. Leveraging session state along with these elements allows you to construct anything from a basic chatbot to a more advanced, ChatGPT-like experience using purely Python code. In this tutorial, we' ll start by walking through Streamlit's chat elements, st.chat_messa

urls.title: Embed your app - Streamlit Docs
urls.description: Embedding Streamlit Community Cloud apps enriches your content by integrating interactive, data-driven applications directly within your pages. Whether you' re writing a blog post, a technical document, or sharing resources on platforms like Medium, Notion, or even StackOverflow, embedding Streamlit apps adds a dynamic component to your content. This allows your audience to interact with your ideas, rather than merely reading about them or looking at screenshots. Streamlit Community Cloud supports both

text:
🎈 Streamlit Community Cloud apps are now easier to embed!

📄 Learn how to add apps to @Medium, @NotionHQ, @Ghost, and other platforms: https://t.co/3Tap7elgXp

urls.title: Version 1.21.0
urls.description: Highlights 📏 Introducing st.divider — a command that displays a horizontal line in your app. Learn how to use this command in its API reference. 🔏 Streamlit now supports the use of a global secrets.toml file, in addition to a project-level file, to easily store and securely access your secrets. Learn more in Secrets management. 🚀 st.help has been revamped to show more information about object methods, attributes, classes, and more, which is great for ...

text:
⚓️ And lastly, anchors in header elements can be turned off by setting anchor=False.

📝 Check out the full release notes: https://t.co/bndQscinja and upgrade to 1.21.0 to try everything out! ✨

🧵 9/9

text:

urls.title: Secrets management - Streamlit Docs
urls.description: Storing unencrypted secrets in a git repository is a bad practice. For applications that require access to sensitive credentials, the recommended solution is to store those credentials outside the repository - such as using a credentials file not committed to the repository or passing them as environment variables. Streamlit provides native file-based secrets management to easily store and securely access your secrets in your Streamlit app. In a global secrets file at ~/.streamlit/secrets.toml for

text:
🔏 Streamlit now supports the use of a global secrets.toml file, in addition to a project-level file, to easily store and securely access your secrets.

🤫 Docs: https://t.co/LEHSHfKNz0

🧵 4/9

urls.description: st.help displays object's doc string, nicely formatted.

urls.title: Getting Started With Snowpark for Python and Streamlit
urls.description: Snowpark at its core provides an API that developers can use to construct DataFrames that are executed lazily on Snowflake's platform. It enables data engineers, data scientists, and developers coding in languages other than SQL such as Python to take advantage of Snowflake's powerful platform without having to first move data out of Snowflake. This enables data application developers to run complex transformations within Snowflake while taking advantage of the built-in unlimited scalability, performance,

urls.title: Connect Streamlit to Snowflake - Streamlit Docs
urls.description: CREATE DATABASE PETS; CREATE TABLE MYTABLE ( NAME varchar(80), PET varchar(80) ); INSERT INTO MYTABLE VALUES (' Mary',' dog'), (' John',' cat'), (' Robert',' bird'); SELECT * FROM MYTABLE; Before you execute the queries, first determine which Snowflake UI / web interface you' re using. The examples below use Snowsight. You can also use Classic Console Worksheets or any other means of running Snowflake SQL statements. To execute the queries in a Worksheet, highlight or select all the queries with your

urls.description: Streamlit makes it easy for you to visualize, mutate, and share data. The API reference is organized by activity type, like displaying data or optimizing performance. urls.title: Caching - Streamlit Docs
urls.description: Streamlit runs your script from top to bottom at every user interaction or code change. This execution model makes development super easy. But it comes with two major challenges: Long-running functions run again and again, which slows down your app. Objects get recreated again and again, which makes it hard to persist them across reruns or sessions. But don' t worry! Streamlit lets you tackle both issues with its built-in caching mechanism. Caching stores the results of slow function calls, so they only

urls.title: Out-Of-Band (OOB) flow Migration Guide  |  Authorization  |  Google for Developers
urls.description: Send feedback Stay organized with collections Save and categorize content based on your preferences. On February 16 2022, we announced plans to make Google OAuth interactions safer by using more secure OAuth flows. This guide helps you to understand the necessary changes and steps to successfully migrate from the OAuth out-of-band (OOB) flow to supported alternatives. This effort is a protective measure against phishing and app impersonation attacks during interactions with Google's OAuth 2.0 authorization

🙏 We want to make working in Streamlit your daily source of joy. What issues have we missed? What new features do we need to develop? Please tell us on the forum! https://t.co/Be6cC1mjNb

Thank you for sharing your work and inspiring us to build amazing things with you! (10/10)

λ Towards stateless Streamlit…

We’re investigating how to expand the ways Streamlit can be hosted, to open new possibilities for sharing, state, compute, and more. This includes implementing a stateless model so it works well in a serverless computing environment. (9/10)

🎈 Streamlit Cloud becomes a hub for community discovery

We want to make it easy to start coding directly on the cloud, show your work to a wide audience, save inspiring and useful code, find relevant apps, meet collaborators, and uncover community-created components. (8/10)

🐞 Debugging is gosh darn delightful

We want to make debugging just as frictionless as building apps—a better in-app display of exceptions and logs, built-in memory and runtime profilers, and improvements to how Streamlit works in the terminal and in your favorite editor. (7/10)

🧩 Custom components v2

Do more with less! We want components to be able to interact with more elements in apps, to make it super easy to publish Python- or HTML-only components, and for you to effortlessly discover and use community-built components. (5/10)
